item.title: In defense of unpolished personal websites
item.author: Ana Rodrigues
item.description: A great message. Be yourself‚Äîlet your imperfections show. Publish your thoughts if you have thoughts to share, even if they‚Äôre incomplete. You won‚Äôt be alone.

item.title: If your content is only on social media, I'm not going to see it
item.author: Cory Dransfeldt
item.description: Same same. Just get an RSS feed, and stop relying on the hegemonic platform silos. The social media landscape is as fractured as it‚Äôs ever been. If you can simulatneously manage a presence on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and Bluesky, then you can certainly add an RSS feed and ideally a Fediverse-compatible account too.

item.title: The philosophy of James‚Äô Coffee Blog
item.author: James' Coffee Blog
item.description: I like this, and I‚Äôve seen other ‚Äúguiding principles‚Äú-type posts before and have been meaning to draft one of my own. It‚Äôs a nice way to remind ourselves why we do this - why we spend the time to write, maintain and build our li‚Äôl homes on the web. Further, it communicates to others what we care about and helps set expectations.

item.title: The web is yours
item.author: James' Coffee Blog
item.description: It‚Äôs so true, you can use the fundamental building blocks of the web to build a highly customized space, a home, just for you on the web. Style it as you want, share what you want, hang out there, be yourself. It‚Äôs so much fun!

item.title: Big Tech Wants You Trapped. The Open Web Sets You Free
item.author: Joan Westenberg
item.description: 100%. It‚Äôs not even hard to get goin‚Äô on the ‚Äúsocial web‚Äù either. Signing up for Mastodon, Pixelfed, creating a blog - there‚Äôs tons of resources for how to do this. So the problem isn‚Äôt so much how these days, rather it is explaining to folks why it‚Äôs important. Joan is one of the best at getting to the core issue.

item.title: I‚Äôm gonna keep making shit and I hope you will too

item.title: The snob RSS Hall of (constructive!) Shame
item.author: Stop at Zona-M
item.description: A shame wall I can get behind. Every website that has a ‚Äúblog‚Äù should have an RSS feed. And if you have an RSS feed, why would you not promote it and have it easily findable? Madness!

item.description: ‚ÄúRestore healthy ecosystems by creating wild, biodiverse spaces‚Äù. But for the Internet. A beautiful, thought-provoking, and very spot-on piece.

item.title: Blogs as third places
item.author: James' Coffee Blog
item.description: I love this idea, and it‚Äôs always been something I aspired to with my site. I‚Äôve long meant for ‚Äúshellsharks‚Äù to be a source of community, and not just a place for me. Over time, it‚Äôs morphed more into my own digital identity and place to post all-things-me, but I still think it can be what James has suggested here, a ‚Äúthird place‚Äù that is inviting, informal, conversational and fun. A place to gather.

item.description: Updates from the fediverse and indieweb projects. A great way to see what‚Äôs happening, and it even features Scrolls!
